_header: Eight is my love if nine go before
Note:
Ringler Jr. (1992)
XRingler Jr., William A. Bibliography and Index of English Verse in Manuscript 1501-1558. London: Mansell, 1992; prepared and completed by Michael Rudick and Susan J. Ringler , TM 379; cf. 2576.
_description: Riddle on the word ‘HIESUS’, Jesus — three or four monorhyming or irregular lines

BodDou257.First Lines:
Viij ys my loue ȝif ix go biforewer viij y gert a boue iij wer
                    wel þer fore…
BodDou257.Last Lines:
…Water yf rorer and taymys broþerSo hat my lemman in non
                    oþer
BodDou257.Editions:
Douce,  Francis. 
             Catalogue of the Printed Books and Manuscripts bequeathed by Francis
                Douce, Esq., to the Bodleian Library
         Oxford: UP, 1840: 41.
Wright,  Thomas,  and  James Orchard Halliwell-Phillipps, eds.  
             Reliquiae Antiquae.
         2 vols. London: Smith, 1845: 2.112.
Silverstein,  Theodore,
                        ed.  
             Medieval English Lyrics.
         York Medieval Texts. London: Edw. Arnold, 1971: 109.

OxfBal354.Transcription:
8 is my trew love do beffore 9 put ynto 5 so wel it will beseme8
                    twyse told 20 betwen he þat redith this a right wottith what I
                    menethis goth by þe letters of the [?] as [?]
OxfBal354.Note: Four monorhyming lines. Last line partly illegible.
OxfBal354.Facsimiles:
Early Manuscripts at Oxford University: Facsimile
                    of Oxford, Balliol MS 354.
         (http://image.ox.ac.uk/show?collection=balliol&manuscript=ms354).
OxfBal354.Editions:
Robbins,  Rossell Hope,
                        ed.  
             Secular Lyrics of the XIV and XV Centuries.
         2nd ed. Oxford: Clarendon, 1955: 253.
Robbins,  Rossell Hope. 
             “Isabel: A Riddling Mistress.” 
             English Language Notes
         1 (1963-64): 1-4: 3.

CamMagPep1236.Transcription:
In 8 is all my loue& 9 be ysette by foreso 8 be yclosyd
                    abouethan 3 is good therfore
CamMagPep1236.Note:
One quatrain, abab, in this MS; solution, ‘Ihesu’, written
                    to right.
CamMagPep1236.Editions:
James,  Montague Rhodes. 
             Bibliotheca Pepysiana: A Descriptive Catalogue of the Library of Samuel
                Pepys. Pt. III: Medieval Manuscripts.
         London, 1923: 3.11.
Robbins,  Rossell Hope,
                        ed.  
             Secular Lyrics of the XIV and XV Centuries.
         2nd ed. Oxford: Clarendon, 1955: 80.
Luria,  Maxwell Sidney,  and  Richard L. Hoffman, eds.  
             Middle English Lyrics.
         New York: Norton, 1974: 121.

CamTCC394.Transcription:
viii is my trewloff do be fore ixpot v thar to well will it
                    reymexviii twysse told xx be tweynehe that herith thys wot what I
                    meyne
CamTCC394.Note:
Variant, added to flyleaf by a hand of early sixteenth century; followed
                    by similar six lines in Latin on the wounds of Christ; ‘Ihessu’
                    written to right of text, and letters ‘h, I, e, ss, u’ written above
                    the numbers.
CamTCC394.Editions:
James,  Montague Rhodes. 
             Catalogue of the
                    Western Manuscripts in the Library of Trinity College, Cambridge.
         4 vols. Cambridge: at the UP, 1900-1904: 1.530.

YorkMinXVIO10.Transcription:
On viii is all my lofe qwen ix goys beforeqware viii is gyrd abofe
                    iii is gude þerforeA thowsand & on made mekyll moyneqwen ten
                    on a hundreth hanges hym all one
YorkMinXVIO10.Note:
Variant spelling ‘IHC’ and M[ary] and J[ohn] weeping when
                    X[Crist] hangs on the C[ross].
